repnme.cdata!:
Lao People's Democratic Republic -
            Agricultural Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Agricultural Development
            Project for Lao People's Democratic Republic were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: project design should be informed by a broad and
            deep analysis of institutional capacities and a specific
            capacity development strategy should be developed as part of
            preparation. This should also include a capacity development
            framework providing a set of proposed interventions and
            indicators which respond to the capacity constraints
            identified at the different levels of project implementation
            and for the staff concerned. Project experience shows that
            the Chief Technical Advisor (CTA) support to the Project
            Coordination Office (PCO) should be more continuous and that
            the CTA expertise should provide support for project and
            program management, including financial management, planning
            and reporting, office and contract management, and
            experience of Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) systems.
            Similarly, inputs of field-based Technical Advisor (TA)
            staff should be programmed to provide a more stable,
            continual support for project staff. Consideration should be
            given to instituting regular Borrower and Bank joint reviews
            of the performance of any TA inputs provided under the credit.

5085130.trustfund:
TF026194-PHRD-AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT
            PROJECT (RECIPIENT-EXECUTED),TF026886-JSDF-LAO PDR: VILLAGE
            INVESTMENT FOR THE POOR PROJECT,TF026179-PHRD-AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT
            PROJECT (BANK-EXECUTED)
5085130.majtheme: Public sector governance,Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Development Project
            aims to reduce rural poverty by improving and increasing
            agricultural production through a community-based approach
            in designing and implementing components which directly
            impact the lives of the poor in the participating provinces
            and districts. There are six components in this project. The
            first component will improve rural infrastructure by
            supporting the rehabilitation of small-scale irrigation
            systems, the rehabilitation of rural access tracks and
            trails, and the improvement of rural water supply and
            sanitation. The second component, Village Investment for the
            Poor, will be a block grant allocated to a district for
            implementing small scale projects identified by the
            villagers themselves. The third component, Improved
            Agricultural Services, will provide for: a) institutional
            strengthening of agricultural services at district,
            provincial, and central levels for the delivery of extension
            services; and b) adaptive research and demonstrations. The
            fourth component will support the policy of transferring
            responsibility for irrigation management and system to water
            user associations. The fifth component, environmental
            management, will finance activities for raising awareness
            among farmers and extension staff of environmental issues.
            The sixth component sill provide support for the
            implementation and coordination units, and in particular
            strengthen capacity in monitoring and evaluation as well as
            in financial management.

repnme.cdata!:
Laos - Agricultural Development Project -
            resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement action plan, provides
            a policy framework for compensation, and rehabilitation to
            project affected persons (PAPs), resulting from
            implementation of the Agricultural Development Program
            Project. Within the legal framework, it reviews the
            provision for partial resettlement, resulting from an
            inventory, and socioeconomic survey, which envisage
            compensation, and entitlement of payments, for
            rehabilitation, costs, and funding sources, while full
            resettlement will be prepared in accordance with the
            National Project Office (NPO), and the Bank. Institutional
            arrangements stipulate that the NPO shall be responsible for
            implementing policy plans, ensuring compensation,
            rehabilitation, and resettlement activities are provided
            accordingly. Mitigation measures specify that: 1)
            agricultural land, and crop losses will be compensated
            through "land for land" arrangements of equal
            productive capacity, and, loss of standing crops, fruits,
            and trees, at market values. Temporary land losses will be
            compensated for lost income, standing crops, and for the
            cost of soil restoration, and damaged infrastructure for a
            period up to two years; 2) residential land, and structures
            losses, will be equivalently replaced if possible, or, cash
            compensation should replace losses without depreciation;
            and, 3) commercial land, structures, and business losses,
            shall be replaced by alternative business, or commercial
            sites, of equal size if possible, or, cash compensation
            should reflect full replacement costs, including cash for
            lost income during the transition period. Grievance
            mechanisms shall be in place, followed by monitoring and
            evaluation practices, to ensure adequate resettlement implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Laos - Agricultural Development Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment reviews
            the Agricultural Development Project's potential
            environmental adversity, and, although it concludes that
            project impacts are generally positive, adequate management,
            and low-cost mitigation should minimize negative effects.
            The main environmental concerns are: natural resource
            management, which in addition to forest degradation, and the
            concomitant problems of flooding, - lower dry season flows,
            and siltation - biodiversity may well be affected by
            ecological disturbances in the Mekong River system; direct
            impacts on project areas, such as the effects on soil
            quality, and salinity risks, drainage impacts on
            sedimentation, surface water, and water-logging, site
            contamination due to residues, and oil spills from
            construction works, and/or toxic chemical residues entering
            the soil, surface and groundwater; and, impacts on health,
            caused by increased disease vectors, and the incidence of
            malaria and other diseases. Mitigation calls for: 1)
            technical training to incorporate uplands conservation,
            fisheries, and wetlands management; 2) development of
            management guidelines to control saline soils, and
            groundwater; 3) contract specifications, to contain worker
            safety, site restoration, waste disposal, environmental
            standards, and be subjected to inspections; and, 4)
            community training, information, and education to be
            provided on health issues, with linkages to national health
            programs. The second volume, addresses development
            strategies for ethnic minorities, and vulnerable groups,

repnme.cdata!:
Laos - Agricultural Development Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment reviews
            the Agricultural Development Project's potential
            environmental adversity, and, although it concludes that
            project impacts are generally positive, adequate management,
            and low-cost mitigation should minimize negative effects.
            The main environmental concerns are: natural resource
            management, which in addition to forest degradation, and the
            concomitant problems of flooding, - lower dry season flows,
            and siltation - biodiversity may well be affected by
            ecological disturbances in the Mekong River system; direct
            impacts on project areas, such as the effects on soil
            quality, and salinity risks, drainage impacts on
            sedimentation, surface water, and water-logging, site
            contamination due to residues, and oil spills from
            construction works, and/or toxic chemical residues entering
            the soil, surface and groundwater; and, impacts on health,
            caused by increased disease vectors, and the incidence of
            malaria and other diseases. Mitigation calls for: 1)
            technical training to incorporate uplands conservation,
            fisheries, and wetlands management; 2) development of
            management guidelines to control saline soils, and
            groundwater; 3) contract specifications, to contain worker
            safety, site restoration, waste disposal, environmental
            standards, and be subjected to inspections; and, 4)
            community training, information, and education to be
            provided on health issues, with linkages to national health
            programs. The second volume, addresses development
            strategies for ethnic minorities, and vulnerable groups,
            though resettlement issues will be addressed in the Social Assessment.

Development strategy for ethnic minority and
            vulnerable groups
